description.p: An Independent_property_definition is a type of Independent_property that is an independent property definition.
An Independent_property_definition is one of the following:

li.p: a class that can have the whole life of an individual product as a member;
a class that can have an individual activity as a member;
li.example: '100 tonnes of water pumped' is an Independent_property_definition.

li.p: a class that can have a state of a individual product as a member.

description.note: The entity type Independent_property_definition defined in this part of ISO 10303 is identical to the entity type property defined in ISO 15926-2.

description.p: A Point_property_definition is a type of Independent_property_definition that has no tolerance.

note.p: A Point_property_definition can be a member of a discrete Property_space such as 'number of bolt holes'. In this case, the absence of a tolerance is reasonable.

A Point_property_definition can be a member of a continuous Property_space such as 'mass'. In this case, the specification of the Point_property_definition for a product design is inevitably an approximation because there must be some tolerance or no individual could ever comply with the design.

description.p: A Property_symmetry is a type of Independent_property that indicates a symmetry of an Independent_property_definition with respect to orientation in space.
A Property_symmetry applied to a Range_property_definition applies to each Point_property_definition within the range.
A Property_symmetry is valid only for instances of Independent_property_definition that are second or higher order tensors.
description.note: Standard instances of Property_symmetry for second and fourth order tensors are specified in Standard_property_symmetry.

description.p: A Property_symmetry_by_library_reference is a Property_symmetry that is defined by reference to an external library.
description.note: Standard instances of Property_symmetry for second and fourth order tensors are specified in Standard_property_symmetry.

explicit.name: item_id
explicit.description: a text string that identifies the the Property_symmetry_by_library_reference.

explicit.name: source_id
explicit.description: a text string that identifies the supplier of definition of the Property_symmetry_by_library_reference.

description.p: A Range_property_definition is a type of Independent_property_definition that has a tolerance.

example.p: 10 Kg to 10.1 Kg is a Range_property_definition.
The specification of this Range_property_definition by a product design indicates that an individual needs to have a mass between 10 Kg and 10.1 Kg to comply with the design.

description.p: A Space_for_property_definition is a relationship between an Independent_property_definition and a Property_space that indicates the physical phenomenon for the Independent_property_definition.

note.p: The relationship is not necessarily classification, but can be understood as follows:

ul.li: if the Independent_property_definition is a Point_property_definition, then the Point_property_definition is a member of the space; and
if the Independent_property_definition is a Range_property_definition, then each point within the range is a member of the space.
the Range_property_definition that is 20 to 25 degrees Celsius; and

example.p: that indicates the physical phenomenon of the range, is a Space_for_property_definition.

explicit.name: related
explicit.description: an Independent_property_definition that has the physical phenomenon indicated.

explicit.name: relating
explicit.description: the Property_space that indicates the physical phenomenon.

description.p: A Standard_property_symmetry is a type of Property_symmetry_by_library_reference that is defined within this part of ISO 10303.
The standard instances of Property_symmetry for second and fourth order tensors specified by this part of ISO 10303 are shown in Table 1.

td.p: symmetric second order tensor in two dimensions with 3 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric second order tensor in two dimensions with 1 independent value - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric second order tensor in three dimensions with 6 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric second order tensor in three dimensions with 1 independent value - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric second order tensor in three dimensions with 3 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric fourth order tensor in two dimensions with 6 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric fourth order tensor in two dimensions with 2 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric fourth order tensor in three dimensions with 2 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric fourth order tensor in three dimensions with 3 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric fourth order tensor in three dimensions with 5 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric fourth order tensor in three dimensions with 9 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric fourth order tensor in three dimensions with 13 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000
symmetric fourth order tensor in three dimensions with 21 independent values - see ISO 10303-104:2000

description.p: These standard instances of class are identified using the methodology of IEC 61360, where:

ul.li: the code is as specified in Table 1;
the supplier is this part of ISO 10303 identified as 'ISO-TS-10303-1099'.

where.label: valid_standard_class
where.description: The supplier shall be 'ISO-TS-10303-1099', and the code shall be one of those listed in Table 1.

description.p: A Symmetry_for_property_definition is a relationship between an Independent_property_definition and a Property_symmetry that indicates the symmetry of the Independent_property_definition.

note.p: The relationship is not necessarily classification, but can be understood as follows:

ul.li: if the Independent_property_definition is a Point_property_definition, then the Point_property_definition is a member of the symmetry; and
if the Independent_property_definition is a Range_property_definition, then each point within the range is a member of the symmetry.
the Point_property_definition that is an isotropic strain of 0.0005; and

example.p: that indicates the nature of the property, is a Symmetry_for_property_definition.

explicit.name: related
explicit.description: an Independent_property_definition that has the symmetry indicated.

explicit.name: relating
explicit.description: the Property_symmetry that indicates the symmetry.
